Award.AwardTitle: Three Dimensional Computer Simulations of Maxwell Equations and Snow Microstructures for Active and Passive Microwave Observations of Snow on Sea Ice in a Changing Climate
Award.AbstractNarration:
Snow cover plays a key role in Arctic sea ice processes, and it has thinned significantly in recent decades. In winter, it insulates sea ice from cold air temperatures, slowing sea ice growth. In spring-summer, snow albedo exerts a control on solar heat absorbed by the sea ice and underlying ocean, impacting ice melt processes. Thus, snow thickness, distribution, and density, can moderate the recovery of the sea ice pack or exacerbate its loss. Airborne and satellite remote sensing are used to monitor snow depth over sea ice. Interpretation of the remotely sensed microwave signals requires accurate models of how the microwaves interact with the snow. This project will develop electromagnetic models that relate the microwave signatures quantitatively to physical parameters of snow. It will contribute to STEM workforce development by providing support for the training of a graduate student. The computer code for the model will be made publicly available and provide a resource for the Arctic science community.

The proposed project will improve the extraction of snow parameters from airborne and spaceborne observations through the modeling of the interaction between snow particles and electromagnetic waves in the microwave region. In particular, the project will generate 3D simulations of the solution to Maxwell's equations in the presence of 3D snow microstructure. Results will be applied to the analysis of active and passive microwave remote sensing data of snow over sea ice. Three-dimensional computer simulations of microstructures of snow that resemble that of real snow will be performed on High Performance Computing (HPC) systems to compute scattering and emission of snow covering sea-ice. The use of large scale high performance computations will permit the simulations to be run over relatively large spatial domains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the project period, we have developed the bicontinuous medium model to computer generate 3D microstructures of snow that resemble that of real snow. We also have developed techniques for 3D full wave numerical solutions of Maxwell equations (NMM3D) for snow over sea ice. We have applied the 3D simulation results to the analysis of active and passive microwave remote sensing data of snow and sea ice. We have generated lookup tables (LUTs) that relate different properties of snow and sea ice to Tb and backscatter responses with NMM3D. For passive remote sensing, we have generated LUTs of Tb at Ku and Ka band for retrieval of snow depth (SD) over sea ice with AMSR-E/2 observations. For active remote sensing, LUTs of backscatter at X-, C- and L-band have been built. Radar backscattering respond to roughness of sea ice and empirical relations have been established between sea ice thickness and sea ice roughness. In addition, our wok also included rough surface effects for both snow/ice and ice/water interface. The roughness of the snow/ice interface weakens the coherent layer effects. Our simulations also demonstrated that both Tb and backscattering are highly related to roughness of the snow/ice interface and the ice/water interface. The snow/ice interface roughness increases Tbs and backscatter more at high frequency and for thick ice, while the ice/water interface roughness increases Tbs and backscatter more at low frequency and for thin ice. Results from the numerical simulations were used to characterize signatures of microwave signals at different bands. 

Intellectual Merit

For the first time, the scattering matrix of the snowpack is computed using this fully coherent approach of NMM3D, including both magnitude and phase. Both bistatic scattering coefficients and brightness temperatures (Tbs) of the snowpack are computed. We also compute the coherence matrix and speckle statistics. Simulation results demonstrate backscattering enhancement effects and coherent layer effects. All these features are not able to be acquired with the radiative transfer theory. The full wave simulation approach departs from traditional approaches of using radiative transfer equation which apply the phase matrix and only describe the incoherent wave interactions. Comparisons between radiative transfer and NMM3D are shown in figures.

Our code of 3D full wave simulation of snowpack is deployed on two of the high performance computing (HPC) infrastructures: the NSF XSEDE Stampede cluster, and the University of Michigan Flux cluster.

Broader Impacts

Snow cover plays a key role in Arctic and Antarctic sea ice processes, and it has thinned significantly in a changing climate. In winter, it insulates sea ice from cold air temperatures, slowing sea ice growth. In spring-summer, snow albedo exerts a control on solar heat absorbed by the sea ice and underlying ocean, impacting ice melt processes. Airborne and satellite active and passive microwave remote sensing measurements of snow and sea ice have been conducted over decades. Quantitative observations of sea ice at multiscale in time and in space are desperate for a long term for sea ice is monitoring sea ice coverage and ice thickness variations. Our research models the scattering, absorption and emission of snow and sea ice. The model has been applied to analysis of active and passive microwave remote sensing data of snow and sea ice, to analyze uncertainties in the retrieval of snow and sea ice and improve the retrieval, and to design future microwave remote sensing measurements including the usage of the signals of opportunities.  Our research also educated and trained students in remote sensing, and earth science applications.  In the broader context of electromagnetic theory, the multiple scattering of electromagnetic waves of surface scattering in the presence of layering and azimuthal asymmetry were completed in this project.
